title: Frank Tower
text:
Frank "Lucky" (or "Lucks") Tower is the subject of an <a href="urban%20legend">urban legend</a> that said that he was a stoker (or fireman, in some versions) who survived the sinking of , , and . There is no evidence that anyone was involved in all three disasters, and no one with the name of Frank Tower on the crew list on any of these vessels' respective voyages; however, there was a survivor named Frank Tower from "Lusitania", and a William Clark who survived both the "Titanic" and "Empress of Ireland" sinkings.
The legend claims that he was a coal stoker on "Titanic", and survived after she sank on her maiden voyage on 14 April 1912. Two years later, on 28 May 1914, Frank was allegedly aboard "Empress of Ireland" when she collided with the <a href="Norway">Norwegian</a> <a href="Collier%20%28ship%20type%29">collier</a> in the <a href="Saint%20Lawrence%20River">Saint Lawrence River</a>. This disaster was considered the worst peacetime maritime disaster in <a href="Canada">Canadian</a> <a href="History%20of%20Canada">history</a>, and Tower was one of only 465 of the 1,477 aboard to survive. During <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, Tower allegedly was serving as a crew member aboard RMS "Lusitania". In the early afternoon of 7 May 1915, she was <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>ed by the <a href="Kaiserliche%20Marine">German</a> <a href="submarine">submarine</a> and sank eighteen minutes later. (It is rumored that he shouted "Now what?!" when the torpedo struck.) Again, Tower escaped the sinking ship, and swam to a nearby lifeboat.
"<a href="Ripley%27s%20Believe%20It%20or%20Not">Ripley's Believe It or Not</a>" reported the legend as if it were verifiably true.
<a href="Clive%20Cussler">Clive Cussler</a> briefly cites this legendary figure in his nonfiction book , in the chapter concerning the "U-20". He relates that after the sinking of "Lusitania", Tower swore that he would take up farming and never go to sea again.
